pomelo_diseases.name: Anthracnose
pomelo_diseases.description: A fungal disease (caused by Colletotrichum spp.) that infects fruit rind, leaves and twigs of pomelo, especially under extended wet/humid conditions.
symptoms: Twig die-back and premature leaf drop on weakened trees
Dark streaks or sunken lesions on fruit rind, often with fungal spores visible
Post-harvest fruit decay or rind breakdown under storage
recommendations: Prune and remove infected twigs and leaves to reduce inoculum sources
Avoid prolonged leaf wetnessâ€”limit overhead irrigation during rainy periods
Apply preventive fungicide sprays, especially during wet season
Ensure good air circulation in canopy and remove dead wood/stressed trees

pomelo_diseases.name: Black Spot
pomelo_diseases.description: A fungal leaf and fruit spot disease that causes blemishes on fruit rind and may reduce yield or marketability of pomelo.
symptoms: Small light yellow, orange-yellow or red-brown spots on the fruit rind that become dark brown/black over time.
Premature fruit drop or rind cracking in heavy infections.
recommendations: Monitor orchards for early lesions around colour-break of fruit and apply fungicide if needed
Remove and destroy fallen infected leaves/fruit to reduce inoculum
Avoid excess canopy wetness and prune for better light/air penetration
Use certified clean planting material and adhere to quarantine regulations where applicable

pomelo_diseases.name: Fruit Borer
pomelo_diseases.description: An insect pest (larvae of citrus fruit borer moth) which bores into pomelo fruit rind and flesh, causing internal damage and fruit drop.
symptoms: Tiny holes on fruit surface often with frass or gum exudation at entrance point.
Internal tunnels or cavities in fruit flesh, resulting in rotting and early fruit drop.
Presence of caterpillar larvae inside fruit if cut open.
recommendations: Monitor fruit and inspect for entry holes and frass (destroy infested fruits on site if detected)
Use pheromone traps or monitoring systems for adult moths (if available)
Apply insecticide treatments at early fruit development stages when larvae are susceptible
Remove fallen/infested fruits, clean tree bases and surrounding debris

pomelo_diseases.name: Melanose
pomelo_diseases.description: A fungal disease (caused by Diaporthe citri) that affects leaves, twigs, and fruits of pomelo, producing raised brown or black specks and rough rind texture.
symptoms: Small corky pustules or raised specks on leaves that may coalesce, giving a sandpaper texture
Brown raised spots on fruit that merge to form corky patches or tear-stain patterns
Infection typically occurs during humid or rainy periods, especially on young tissues
recommendations: Prune and remove dead wood or twigs that harbor the fungus
Apply copper-based fungicides during periods of active shoot growth or before rainy conditions
Avoid overhead irrigation to reduce leaf wetness duration
Improve orchard sanitation and air circulation to minimize humidity
Handle fruits carefully during harvest to avoid wounds that may allow secondary infection

pomelo_diseases.name: Mite Damage
pomelo_diseases.description: Damage caused by microscopic mites feeding on pomelo rind and leaves, producing cosmetic damage, rind roughening, bronzing or silvery patches.
symptoms: Silvery or bronzed appearance on fruit rind when feeding occurs early; rough texture when feeding during early growth.
On mature fruits, appearance of brown stain or bronzing if mites feed later in development.
Yellowish patches, dull or bronze discoloration on the leaves.
recommendations: Monitor mite populations regularly especially from spring through summer
Use hand-lens and sample fruit inside canopy
Maintain canopy density and avoid over-thinning
Apply appropriate miticides when thresholds are exceeded (especially for fresh-market fruit) and rotate modes of action to avoid resistance.
Combine treatments with good horticultural practices: avoid water stress, improve tree health, remove alternate hosts or debris.
